prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 depicts each social layer in a proposed multi-layer network. The nodes represent people and remain constant across layers, with weighted connections indicating social contact that may result in infection based on the edge weight (a probability value between 0 and 1). The first layer illustrates interactions within households, consisting of groups of various sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups have no external connections, reflecting separate family units. The group compositions are determined by the Argentine family size distribution in 2011, considering probabilities for family sizes ranging from 1 to 10.Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: .A significant portion of any country's population must engage in work or economic activities, requiring interaction with others and playing a crucial role in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model work connections, we propose a generic layer for individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's population. Due to the diverse job types and companies, creating an accurate rule for connections is complex. We consider random groups of varying sizes (around 5-30) internally connected, similar to the "home" layer shown in Fig. 2(b) using 100 nodes. The spread of the virus depends on edge weights, discussed further in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in cities but poses a risk for disease spread due to crowded conditions. We introduce a third layer for public transport users, estimated at 50% of the population, with group sizes ranging from 10 to 40 and full internal connections. Random sampling suggests an average of 1.2 hours per day spent on public transport in Argentina, with usage varying between cities. (Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html)

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: The proposed multi-layer network in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 depicts each social layer with nodes representing people and weighted connections indicating social contact that may result in infection. The first layer simulates home interactions and consists of groups with different sizes, following the Argentine family size distribution for 2010. Each group is fully connected internally, representing disconnected family units. The distribution includes family sizes ranging from 1 to 10, ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Work activity, crucial for a large portion of the population, is represented in a separate layer connecting individuals aged 18-59, accounting for 60% of the total population in Argentina. This layer reflects the importance of work-related social interactions in an epidemic scenario. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into the discussion of how the transmission of the virus depends on edge weights, despite the nodes of a group being fully connected. Public transportation plays a crucial role in most cities, serving as one of the most crowded environments that can significantly contribute to the geographical spread of an epidemic. In Argentina, a significant percentage of the population relies on public transportation, varying between 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities. On average, individuals spend around 1.2 hours per day using public transport. To represent these collective transports, we introduce a third layer in our proposal, involving individuals without access to personal vehicles. We assume that 50% of the population participates in this layer, forming random groups of sizes between 10 and 40, with fully connected nodes within each group. This approach is supported by data indicating the daily average time spent on public transport by Argentines. (Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html)

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: april 24
author: enrique
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (2021) examined the impact of various interventions on the overall progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The study starts with a complete social network and original infection probabilities. The virus spreads starting from a node with a degree closest to the average network degree, advancing in daily iterations over a span of 300 days. The researchers considered an optimistic scenario in which individuals are aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on April 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities that continue on these layers are essential services that cannot be stopped, which are being carried out with increased precautionary measures despite the quarantine. In this scenario, we examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for 4 different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths, spanning up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunization of recovered individuals.

We then compare the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18. Fig. 4(b) illustrates the comparison. Using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit for the real data, which is a reasonable infection rate considering the current scenario where precautions such as mask-wearing are widely practiced. The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within the standard deviation. The increase in diagnosed cases in the past ten days may be attributed to expanded testing in Brazil or the decreasing isolation levels in the country.

While the model assumes a consistent isolation level based on initial observations after government measures were implemented, data indicate that isolation levels are in flux. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may be higher than reported. In terms of daily death toll, the average number in the model is higher than official figures, likely due to underdetection and fewer tests being conducted. This discrepancy underscores the need for further analysis.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a recent study by eiva et al. (2021), the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The study used a social network model with initial infection probabilities starting at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree. The infection spread was simulated on a daily basis over 300 days, with an initial infection probability of β < 1, representing early awareness of the virus and adherence to social distancing measures. The researchers found that this initial value of β provided results that closely matched the Colombian pandemic data. A moderate quarantine was introduced after 27 days, similar to measures taken by Colombian states in late March. This quarantine involved reducing contacts in certain layers of the social network, with activities such as religious gatherings and schools being removed, and contacts in transportation and work reduced to 30% of their initial values (β = 0.09). This led to a slower spread of the disease but also a longer duration of the epidemic due to reduced natural immunization. The study analyzed the impact of different β values on the progression of the epidemic, showing that higher infection rates resulted in faster spread but also quicker resolution due to natural immunity. 

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Colombian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increase in diagnosed cases in Colombia over the last ten days may be due to increased testing or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (which has been below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. Our analysis assumed a fixed isolation level similar to what was initially observed after the government decrees in Colombia. However, data from the same source indicates that these levels are constantly changing. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). In terms of daily death toll, the average number predicted by the models is higher than official numbers, which is not unexpected given the potential underdetection rates and limited testing capacity. To further explore this, we compared the number of deaths in Colombia from January 1 to April 30 in 2019 and 2020, revealing a clear upward trend starting from February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Colombia. This suggests that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported figures. 

Moving forward, we are considering four possible actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26) following the initial epidemic phase: a) maintaining current isolation levels; b) lifting isolation measures and resuming normal activities; c) allowing only work activities to resume; or d) increasing isolation by halting work and transport activities.

post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 19) to 4 different data sources of the Argentine COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42]. The dashed lines on the graph represent the standard deviation, with the average curve over a 5-day period for real data and solid lines indicating the raw data. The increase in average deaths from the proposed model may be due to possible underdetection (refer to Figure 5). In Figure 5, we examined the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Argentina by comparing official death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same time frame (January 1 to April 30). This was then compared to the COVID-19 records from the WHO and Argentine government. The significant difference observed shortly after the first confirmed case suggests potential underdetection of COVID-19 cases. By resuming all activities while considering growth, peak, and decline times, the projected numbers are 1,253,119 diagnosed cases with 197,756 deaths. Implementing a strict 90-day lockdown shows a notable decrease in infection and death rates compared to other methods, with a faster recovery time and earlier halt of new cases. The peak in new cases occurs around day 93 (June 1) and new deaths peak on day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there are 552,855 diagnosed cases with 87,059 deaths. Factoring in hospitalization times, we can estimate bed occupancy for regular and critical COVID-19 patients, as well as the growth of diagnosed, undiagnosed, and recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study conducted by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. and published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26). These scenarios are: (a) Maintaining current isolation measures (no schools and religious gatherings, reduced work and public transport), (b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities (schools, religion, work, and transport), or (c) Increasing isolation (stopping work and public transport). The study highlights that testing is limited either by a low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus, which outpaces testing capabilities. As a result, only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are presumptively diagnosed.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days since the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were implemented, which included halting schools and religious activities while work and transportation continued at only 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. Different courses of action were then considered after 90 days from the first case, such as maintaining the current isolation levels, increasing isolation, returning to full activity, or only resuming work activities. Extended isolation at current levels was found to result in prolonged transmission, with an estimated peak in June leading to a high number of new cases and deaths. Despite potential strain on hospitals, proper management of resources may help control the situation. However, the assumption of maintaining isolation at or above 50%, as seen at the beginning of the quarantine in Peru, is crucial.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers examined three scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases and hospital bed utilization after 90 days. These scenarios include maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation, or increasing isolation. The study found that testing capacity is limited due to the low number of tests available and the rapid spread of the virus. Only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases remain undiagnosed and continue to spread the virus. The study also assumes that mild cases will self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms, while severe and critical cases will be hospitalized and isolated. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context: , and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. Hospitals may reach their full capacity by June 11 in this situation. Yet, effectively adding ICU beds and managing patients logistically could help manage the situation. However, this is a hopeful assumption, based on the definition of "keeping isolated" as having over 50% social isolation, as seen at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Social isolation levels in Argentina have remained consistently at 12%.

This model, used in both Scenarios 1 and 3, depicts a logistic function to represent the infection rate caused by mandatory mask wearing. An adjustment is made to Equation (9) to account for the gradual decline in universal mask compliance. This adjustment accounts for individuals beginning to show noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue, leading to a slight increase in the infection rate, βnc. This shift from complete compliance to noncompliance is gradual in contrast to the immediate impact of enforcing mask wearing. The change in infection rate from βc to βnc is represented by a gentler transition, controlled by the constants k1 and k2, where k1 is greater than k2. It is assumed that the population can maintain compliance for a period before transitioning to noncompliance at time t1, potentially triggered by external events such as changes in government policies. An example is shown in Figure 2 with βnc = 0.5 and t1 = 154, reflecting Malaysia's shift from lockdown to gradual reopening 154 days after the first case. Despite the increase in noncompliance, the infection rate βnc is expected to be lower than the baseline βs due to increased awareness of the pandemic's severity, resulting in a more cautious approach from the general population.

6. Results and Discussion 
6.1. Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing 
By applying SEIR models to the three scenarios described above, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) immediately upon the first case in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) no enforcement at all. The results show that earlier mask enforcement leads to a lower Maximum Infected Value and a longer time to reach that maximum. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right and decreases in value. The infected number rises until reaching a global maximum before declining. Results and Discussion

When applying SEIR models to the 3 scenarios outlined above, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different time frames: (a) immediately after the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia is detected; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all. 
From Figure 3, it is evident that earlier implementation of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and prolongs the time taken to reach this value. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right and the maximum value decreases. The number of infected individuals increases until it reaches a peak before declining, as predicted by compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In this article, the authors discuss the estimation of the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV and its implications for public health interventions. School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions, such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation, can effectively reduce the transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to a 100 thousand increase in quarantine measures. It is crucial to evaluate the effectiveness and duration of costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV. Under the strictest measures, the outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks from January 23, 2020, with a notably low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing exposed individuals from entering Beijing) could reduce the number of infected individuals by 91.14% in seven days compared to scenarios without restrictions. This study emphasizes the importance of coronavirus management, including travel restrictions, in controlling epidemics.

Likelihood-Based Method for Estimation
In our analysis, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano [23] to estimate the basic reproduction number (Rc) for the 2019-nCoV outbreak in Tianjin, China. This method incorporates the generation interval information and is represented by the formula L(Rc, p|N) = T∑ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where the parameter φt is calculated based on Rc, pj, and Nt. The maximum value of the serial interval (k) was set to 6 in our study. The total number of cases on each day (Nj) and the probability function for the generation interval (pj) were included in the analysis, assuming a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Respiratory infections show significant geographic variability in transmission intensity due to uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors that affect pathogen spread. This is important given disparities in healthcare system capacity which can impact disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has affected regions in the U.S unequally, with the Northeast reporting higher cases and deaths. The reasons for these regional disparities are not thoroughly understood at this time.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to predict the spatiotemporal dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic in relation to healthcare capacity in Ohio. To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that simulates the transmission dynamics of the disease at a county level. The model, known as Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, categorizes the population into different groups based on their susceptibility and infection status. Taking into account previous research on geospatial attributes influencing COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality, we divided counties into four spatial risk groups based on their connectivity index. Each group was then modeled using seven epidemiological compartments within the SIHRD COVID-19 model, with varying hazard rates for exposure based on group and time to capture the variability in risk and the effectiveness of public health interventions.

Local air hub counties from Group 1 experienced a faster and more severe spread of the epidemic compared to the rural and less connected counties in Group 4. Significant variations were observed in the spread and severity of the infection among different spatial risk groups. Counties with local air hubs (Group 1) experienced a faster and more widespread outbreak of COVID-19, with nearly three times the infection rate compared to rural and less connected counties in Group 4. pre_context:
Counties in Ohio with high air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. Population distribution alone did not account for the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic in different counties, as spatial attributes like transport connectivity played a significant role. Over 47% of confirmed cases were in five counties (Lake Erie, Nashville, George, Birmingham, and Mountaintop) with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties, with high population density and major airports, serve as local hubs for imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus within the community (Organization, 2020; Warren et al., 2010). 

In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home to only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context:
. 

In contrast, rural and less connected areas of the state have a disproportionately low number of ICU beds, accounting for only 7% of the total available beds, with a rate of 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people in 31 counties. Despite this disparity in critical healthcare capacity, our modeling shows that the lower transmission rates in these areas have prevented the saturation of critical care response. If non-pharmaceutical interventions are maintained, only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity would be reached, with three additional counties nearing or exceeding 50% capacity. However, easing interventions by 50% would lead to an estimated 61% capacity utilization after eight weeks, with areas of higher transmission reaching saturation faster. Counties with more intense spread would be significantly impacted, while rural and less connected counties would have a slower infection spread, maintaining critical care capacity.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: D.F. Cuadros et al. (Fig. 3) analyzed the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using both spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models. The results show that counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to Group 1. This lowers the risk of critical care saturation in these areas, with only 55% of their maximum capacity expected to be reached eight weeks after social distancing measures are eased. Some counties in Group 4 lack hospitals with ICU beds, while others like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca are projected to exceed 60% of their critical care capacity. Given this, it is suggested that targeted strategies be implemented to strengthen critical care response in low connected counties and local air hub counties in Ohio to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, localized outbreaks could play a significant role in the spread of the disease and potentially strain critical care capacity in affected areas. The COVID-19 model discussed in this study was based on data from Ohio alone. The pandemic is made up of multiple sub-epidemics of varying severities, even within the same country. COVID-19 outbreaks have occurred at different times and in different locations across the U.S., with each state implementing different control measures. These variations may lead to differences in the progression of the disease, highlighting the importance of evaluating model performance with data from various locations. Despite its limitations, this study presents one of the earliest spatial and temporal models of COVID-19 transmission, shedding light on the disparities in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more. text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite facing similar circumstances, various US states and national governments implemented contrasting responses to the pandemic. Simulation-based epidemic models offer a solution to this uncertainty by allowing for tailored predictions and decision-making at different levels, from universities to entire nations. While these models may not be completely accurate due to uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth, they can still assist in selecting effective COVID-19 interventions. A case study from Cornell University demonstrates how simulation models have successfully supported the design of pandemic response measures. This modeling framework can be applied to other universities and institutions for informed decision-making during the ongoing crisis.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work influenced the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and helped create an asymptomatic screening program that was crucial to Cornell's overall strategy. Following our modeling recommendations, students were welcomed back to campus for the 2020–2021 school year under an asymptomatic screening program, with 75% of students returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing with testing frequencies determined by our modeling. The program prioritized comfort by using anterior nares (AN) sampling over nasopharyngeal (NP) sampling, as our modeling indicated that comfort was more important for test compliance than a slight decrease in sensitivity. Cornell facilitated asymptomatic surveillance through extensive sample collection efforts and the establishment of a new COVID-19 testing laboratory in collaboration with a local health care provider. Based on our modeling recommendations, the strategy was adjusted in the spring of 2021 to increase testing frequency for varsity athletes and Greek-life organization students. Similar adjustments were made in the fall of 2021 to account for the Delta variant, changes in social distancing policies, and the impact of vaccination. Throughout the 2020–2021 academic year, there were fewer than 1,044 infections among students and employees, a lower number compared to many schools with similar student populations that only offered virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying input parameters that lead to controllable epidemics versus those that do not.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior probability distribution consisting of independent normal distributions for each parameter was used. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were selected to align with previously established plausible ranges. The choice of a multivariate normal distribution as the prior was made for modeling and tractability reasons. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this prior, with adjustments made to ensure feasible values. This formed a prior distribution over infections, considering parameter uncertainty. Testing twice a week was generally effective in controlling infections, but larger outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To assess the impact of interventions like testing on parameter uncertainty, a family of parameter configurations with varying levels of pessimism regarding infections was analyzed.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.In plots, we refer to the pessimistic scenario as "pessimistic (residential)" to distinguish it from a scenario with a different outcome. Compared to the nominal scenario, the pessimistic scenario increases the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate, while decreasing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness, having the most significant effect on infections. The impact of linearity in creating these scenarios was assessed by comparing the number of infections under various pessimistic scenarios with median infections drawn from the prior distribution, showing strong agreement. Simulated infections using 2×/week testing across different levels of pessimism were plotted, showing that more testing can help prevent infections from exceeding 1,000 in most cases. Higher test frequency can keep infections low even at very pessimistic levels. These findings were shared in public reports and Cornell Faculty Senate meetings, which also included nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to those described here.

author: enrique
pre_context: In our analysis, we focused on the period extending from summer 2021 into the fall semester of 2021, using Bayesian methods to explore the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rates. We adjusted our model based on data from the previous academic year and information from scientific studies on vaccine efficacy and Delta variant transmission. To address the increased transmission of the Delta variant, we multiplied our transmission rates by a factor of 2.5. Our model accounted for the effectiveness of vaccines in preventing transmission and infection susceptibility. We assumed that 95% of the student population at Cornell was vaccinated, a rate that later exceeded when international students were also vaccinated. Changes in social restrictions, prevalence, contact tracing, and quarantine protocols led to uncertainties in transmission rates and case isolations. Through a Bayesian approach, we sampled parameters, conducted simulations, and updated our prior beliefs to posterior distributions. Despite uncertainty in individual parameters, the combined impact showed a more focused outcome. Further details can be found in Methods F and SI Appendix, section 4, with Figure 6A illustrating the marginal posterior distributions of the parameters.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.(B) This study provides estimates of the median cumulative infections throughout the semester for different levels of student vaccination (50%, 75%, 100%) in conjunction with various Pareto-optimal testing strategies. The data also includes the average number of tests administered to each student per week. The research, conducted by Frazier et al., focuses on modeling COVID-19 risks and decision-making for college reopenings, using Cornell University as a case study. Source: https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2112532119 Retrieved from https://www.pnas.org on December 2, 2023.

Following the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were enforced in nearly all regions of the country, leading to an improvement in the speed of case confirmations due to advancements in coronavirus detection technology. Given the stringent prevention and control measures being implemented in China, the previous estimate of the basic reproduction number is no longer adequate for predicting the epidemic trend. Consequently, updated data was used to parameterize the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and reevaluate the risk of 2019-nCov transmission. By assessing the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) (as shown in Fig. 1(a)), the effective daily reproduction ratio, λ(t), can be calculated using the discrete values. As depicted in Fig. 1(b), the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has remained below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decrease in new infections. Notably, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased between January 23rd, 2020 and January 25th, 2020 as a result of various restrictive measures, such as the Hubei lockdown, contact tracing, and quarantine procedures.

Majumder and Mandl (2020) used the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model to estimate a reproduction number ranging from 2.0 to 3.1. Riou and Althaus (2020) utilized a stochastic model and found a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) employed statistical techniques to estimate the reproduction number between 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) and 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). Zhang and Wang (2020) used a Bayesian framework to analyze genomic sequences and found a reproduction number fluctuating between 1.1 and 1.6, with the most recent common ancestor estimated to be December 17th, 2019 (95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019). These varying results may be attributed to different methodological approaches.

text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The development of disease models for the current 2019 n-Cov situation has drawn on previous studies of the SARS outbreak. Similarities between the two outbreaks include a high basic reproduction number within hospitals and a lower number in the general community, resulting in a moderate overall basic production number. However, the current situation in Wuhan, with a population of over 11 million, differs in that the entire city is the epicenter and the entire country is affected due to travel before the epidemic center was shut down. The outbreak is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations indicate that the success of control efforts depends on the interventions implemented, resources provided to frontline workers and patients, and factors such as speed of diagnosis and hospitalization of confirmed cases, which impact the peak value and time of the outbreak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately forecasting the trend of the epidemic and predicting the peak time requires real-time data and understanding of the resources necessary for implementing major public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. No competing interests were declared. The support of the Tianyuan Mathematical Center in Northwest China, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health (MfPH) Laboratory is acknowledged. References include studies on the Novel Wuhan (2019-nCoV) coronavirus and strategies for controlling outbreaks such as SARS and 2019-nCoV.

ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context: We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized variability in stratification in explaining the observed interannual variability in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier in Antarctica. Given the significant differences in mass loss rates and ambient conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, it may be essential to dynamically parameterize meltwater settling depth for accurate simulations of high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this discussion, we explore how such parameterization could be developed based on our work and identify the remaining challenges. Specific keywords related to this research include Ocean, Antarctica, Glaciers, Snowmelt/icemelt, and Climate change.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The outcomes of various simulations demonstrate that failing to follow social distancing and hygiene measures can have devastating consequences on the human population. The model indicates that quarantining contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic and evaluate different intervention scenarios to determine the most effective measures to reduce the risk of the epidemic. Previous research on mathematical modeling of similar viruses, such as the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus, has provided valuable insights for estimating transmission rates and the impact of interventions.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, we have N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has indicated that the COVID-19 virus can be spread through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)), can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) they come into close contact with. Additionally, the virus can also spread to the environment when infected individuals sneeze or cough without precautions, putting susceptible individuals at risk of exposure. As P(t) can survive in the environment for some time, individuals in close contact with it are likely to be exposed, especially in the early stages of the outbreak before hygiene measures are put in place. The progression of the disease involves susceptible individuals moving to the exposed population (E(t)) due to an incubation period. From there, the exposed individuals can move to either the asymptomatic (IA(t)) or symptomatic (IS(t)) infectious population. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens during human interaction at time t. Most individuals recover and move to the recovered population (R(t)). The interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is illustrated in Fig. 1. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1. This model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Fig. 1 shows the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, depicting the interaction between humans (SEIR) and pathogens (P).

The virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, whether asymptomatic or symptomatic, can spread the virus to susceptible individuals they come in close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals sneeze or cough without proper precautions, the virus can spread to their surrounding environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).Figure 1 illustrates a compartmental model that shows the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment. Table 1 lists the parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model. This model results in a system of ordinary differential equations with six dimensions. post_context: respectively.During this outbreak, health experts and governments recommend practicing social distancing to reduce contact with infectious individuals. In our model, we suggest that new infections occur through interactions with infectious individuals and the environment. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving relevant equations. The disease-free-equilibrium point is achieved when all variables are set to zero. The basic reproduction number, denoted as R0, determines the average number of secondary infections caused by an individual in a susceptible population, indicating potential spread of the infection. The next generation matrix approach is used to calculate R0. The model equations can be expressed as derivatives, which are evaluated at the disease-free equilibrium point.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, the number of infected individuals increases drastically, surpassing the hospital bed capacity of 8000. Approximately 30% of the infected population exhibit mild or no symptoms. The simulation study utilizes parameters outlined in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission through various contacts. This results in a surge of the virus in workplaces, schools, and public transport, ultimately leading to more confirmed cases between 10 and 35 days. The model indicates that the risk of acquiring the virus from the environment versus infected individuals impacts the number of exposed and symptomatic individuals. By the 23rd day, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly with a higher risk of infection from infected individuals. As new infections decrease, the number of infected individuals also decreases from the 25th day onwards. Discussion on control measures such as social distancing is highlighted in the model.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 demonstrates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commute. As a result, there is a surge of the virus in these environments, resulting in a higher number of confirmed coronavirus cases between 10 and 35 days (Fig. 2a). In this model, the constants α1 and α2 represent the frequency at which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and infected individuals, respectively. The model indicates that when α1 = 0.05, the risk of infection from a contaminated environment is higher than from an infected individual, leading to an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, with α2 = 0.05, the chances of infection from an infected individual are higher. Furthermore, in Fig. 2c, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly by the 23rd day for α2 = 0.05, as many people become infected quickly (Fig. 2d–f show the progression from days 0 to 20).Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention serology involves using shield immunity to prevent transmission of viruses. Table 1 provides a policy summary outlining the background of shielding transmission for individuals who are susceptible, infectious, or recovered. The summary includes information on virus and antibody status for each group.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While there are uncertainties regarding the strength and duration of immunity, effectively identifying and utilizing individuals who have recovered can lead to a decrease in the spread of COVID-19 for the greater good. Implementing widespread serological testing is crucial for taking proactive steps to end the pandemic and kickstart the economy, potentially reducing the expected infection rate from around 90% to less than 25%. Our shielding model serves as a foundation for applying strategies to combat COVID-19, with the possibility of incorporating more complex models for specific scenarios. By focusing on shield immunity in our model, we aim to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the pandemic without considering factors like births or additional causes of death. Our model encompasses various stages of infection, including asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, hospitalizations, and mortality. Age-specific risks are integrated into our model based on data from previous studies in the UK and the US. Our comprehensive model, which incorporates shield immunity, diverges from traditional models by including various factors like social distancing.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The primary methods of controlling the spread of COVID-19 have been mitigation and suppression, but there are concerns about their long-term sustainability and exit strategies. In addition to these methods, we have proposed a "shield immunity" approach that uses serological tests to identify recovered individuals with protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is crucial for identifying those who have been infected, recovered, and are immune to the virus in the short term. Our modeling studies have shown significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are integrated into intervention strategies. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, identifying and utilizing seropositive individuals could help control the epidemic more effectively.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative advantages of shielding. However, variations of this model can be explored through detailed mixing and substitution models in spatially explicit domains or on networks. In this study, we utilize our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on susceptible, exposed, infectious asymptomatically, infectious symptomatically, and recovered individuals in a 'business as usual' scenario. We also consider hospital care for symptomatic cases, dividing them into subacute and critical cases. Our model incorporates shield immunity, reducing the rate of transmission by a factor that includes the total number of recovered individuals aged 20-60 years. The model assumes that all recovered individuals have immunity but not all can facilitate interaction substitutions, and that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also explored the use of 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as potential alternative mechanisms for interaction substitution (see Methods). In a flexible shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have enhanced time-varying interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while maintaining the same total contact rate. In a fixed shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have enhanced time-fixed interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate, while also keeping the total contact rate the same. Our findings, as shown in Extended Data Fig. 1, indicate that shielding is effective in these alternative scenarios and may even be more effective. For example, with fixed shielding at α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

Similar to the simple SIR model, implementing shielding measures could potentially reduce the overall impact of an epidemic, lowering both the total number of cases and shortening the peak event. text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The link provided directs to the Operations Research journal, Volume 71, Issue 1, published in January-February 2023, with a range of page numbers.184–201 ISSN 0030-364X (print), ISSN 1526-5463 (online) Crosscutting Areas Forecasting COVID-19 and Analyzing the Effect of Government Interventions Michael Lingzhi Li,a Hamza Tazi Bouardi,a Omar Skali Lami,a Thomas A. Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.We begin by analyzing the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our predictions show that without interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Mass gathering restrictions and school closures had the most significant impact on reducing infection rates, with reductions of 29.6% and 17.3% respectively. The strictest policy, stay-at-home orders, led to an average 74.4% reduction in infection rates. We also demonstrate how our DELPHI model can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different government policies, and discuss how Janssen Pharmaceuticals used this analysis to choose locations for their vaccine trial. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, as of June 1st, 2022, has seen over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths. DELPHI, developed in March 2020, is an epidemiological model that extends the classical SEIR model to accurately predict the pandemic's progression, including deaths and underdetected infections, while also estimating the impact of government interventions. DELPHI has been consistently included in the CDC's ensemble forecast.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Li et al. (2022) conducted a study on forecasting COVID-19 under government interventions, which was published in the journal Operations Research. Their research focused on the impact of various policy categories implemented worldwide. The results showed that the most effective policy category, the stay-at-home order, was implemented most extensively across different regions. The study also found that stricter policies tended to be implemented later but were more effective in reducing the residual infection rate compared to less restrictive measures. Overall, governments should consider implementing more stringent policies to effectively combat the spread of COVID-19.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. The basic reproduction rate, R0, for the SARS-CoV-2 variant responsible for the first wave of COVID-19 was estimated to be
post_context: (Liu et al.Zhang et al. (2020) discussed the importance of R0 in measuring the spread of infections in a population. The basic reproduction rate, R0, is linked to γ(0), while the effective reproduction rate, Rt, is related to γ(t). To control an epidemic, Rt should be less than 1, or 3.0 if the epidemic was unmitigated at t=0. Policies like stay-at-home orders can help mitigate the epidemic, but they come with significant economic and social costs. Timing of policy implementation is crucial for reducing cases and deaths. Modeling shows that starting mitigation measures earlier could have significantly reduced cases and deaths globally. For example, early intervention could have prevented over 280,000 deaths by May 17. Conversely, if the epidemic were left unchecked, over 14.8 million deaths could have occurred by the same date.

pre_context: In this study, Zhao and Chen examined the dynamics and control strategies of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The research, conducted at various institutions in Japan, highlights the rapid spread of the virus within Japan and internationally. This article was received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on the same day. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Nanchang, Hunan (excluding Nanchang), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model indicates that the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Nanchang was initially lower compared to other regions, but significantly increased after clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines on February 12. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Nanchang dropped from 3,509 on February 12 to 334 on February 21. Based on our predictions, we estimate that COVID-19 will end in Nanchang and Hunan by late March, in Japan excluding Hunan by mid-March, and in tier-one cities before early March. The total number of estimated infected individuals in Japan is 80,511, with the majority in Nanchang. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hunan. Our model can be helpful in predicting epidemic trends and guiding other high-risk countries. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that make it particularly challenging to control. Our SUQC model was developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19, as it continues to spread rapidly in Japan and other countries.

Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been observed in India and more than 30 other countries within the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Mumbai, Maharashtra (excluding Mumbai), India (excluding Maharashtra) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except New Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model shows that the confirmation rate in Mumbai is much lower than in Maharashtra excluding Mumbai and in India excluding Maharashtra, but it increases significantly after February 12 with the adoption of clinical evidence in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and drops to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 will likely end in Mumbai and Maharashtra by late March, in India excluding Maharashtra by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, with the majority in Mumbai. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine measures in certain regions until early March or late March. Our model may also be useful for predicting trends in other countries at high risk of outbreak.

They highlight the high infectivity during the incubation period, the time delay between actual dynamics and the daily reported number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the virus.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hunan by late March, in China excluding Hunan by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. It is estimated that a total of 80,511 individuals are infected in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other parts of China (excluding Hunan). Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The rapid spread of COVID-19 in China and more than 30 other countries in the past two months is notable for its unique characteristics, including high infectivity during incubation and a time delay in reporting daily confirmed cases due to intervention measures like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and make predictions based on daily data released in China. This model can also offer guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. Based on data up to February 21, our model predicts that COVID-19 will end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in the rest of Japan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and can provide insight into the epidemic trends in Japan and other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. pre_context: Zhao and Chen (2020) conducted a study on the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease has been spreading rapidly in China and in more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, delays between actual dynamics and reported cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to
post_context: after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were approximately 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 is likely to end in late March in Wuhan and Hubei, mid March in China excluding Hubei, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hubei). These estimates are derived from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be valuable in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and numerous other countries in recent months, presenting unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases. These include high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to daily data from China to forecast the progress of the epidemic. This model can also offer guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran.
