author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Email from chenh@big.ac.cn dated February 29, 2020, with revisions on March 4, 2020, and acceptance of the same date.

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and to over 30 countries in the past two months. It exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

In this study, a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to better analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, specifically parameterizing the effects of control measures. 

This model was applied to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions of China, showing that effective quarantine and control measures have helped contain the spread of the virus. The confirmation rate of Chongqing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Chongqing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chongqing, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Chongqing), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please keep in mind that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some degree of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also help predict the epidemic's trajectory and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and over 30 other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, which has been applied to China's data to forecast the epidemic's trajectory and offer guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Introduction: Within the past two months, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and across more than 30 countries. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual spread dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on transmission.

Methodology: In this study, we introduce a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to capture the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly incorporates the effects of various control measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Findings: By applying the SUQC model to the daily reported data of confirmed cases, we analyze the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan), and four major cities in China. Our results highlight that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, post-January 30, all regions exhibited an R value less than 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be understood with some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should continue until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can be valuable in predicting the epidemic's trajectory and offering quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and numerous other countries. Key features of COVID-19 include high infectivity during the incubation period, delays between actual dynamics and daily confirmed case numbers, and the impact of intervention measures like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Chinese data to predict the epidemic's progression. It can also provide guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. This article is published by Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature in 2020.

pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020 Background: The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in South Korea and more than 30 other countries in the past two months has raised concerns. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Methods: A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and assess the effectiveness of control measures. Results: The SUQC model was applied to daily data on confirmed cases in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), South Korea (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in South Korea. The analysis showed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, indicating uncontrolled spread of the virus. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, suggesting that quarantine and control measures effectively curbed the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of South Korea excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for South Korea excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in South Korea, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of South Korea (excluding Hubei).The estimates provided by a deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can also be helpful in predicting the epidemic trend and offering guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading globally, with unique characteristics that require special attention. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict the epidemic trend using daily data from South Korea. This model can also provide valuable guidance for countries facing a high risk of outbreak. Copyright © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

pre_context: In order to evaluate the performance of the model, data was analyzed. The blue curve in Fig. 1B shows the model fitting results, with blue dots representing predicted numbers of confirmed infections and red dots representing observed numbers. Prior to Feb 12, reported confirmed cases were based on nucleic acid diagnosis, with both nucleic acid and clinical diagnosis results provided from Feb 12 to 14. From Feb 15 to 21, only the total confirmed numbers were reported. By comparing daily nucleic acid diagnosis data points, the model appears to predict the trend well. Clinical diagnosis was implemented as an additional criterion by Chengdu medical agencies after Feb 12, leading to an increase in confirmed cases. Despite this, some infected individuals remain unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. The model predicts a total of 62,577 infected individuals in Chengdu, with an end time of 147 days from Jan 28, 2020. By analyzing stage I data from Chengdu, the model can predict epidemic trends assuming no strict quarantine measures. Parameters were inferred from the first 10 daily data points starting from Jan 20.The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1).The significant disparity between predictions based on stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data highlights the effectiveness of preventative measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, in controlling the outbreak of the epidemic. Following the implementation of stricter quarantine and traffic control measures in Chengdu to curb the spread of COVID-19, we also analyzed the stage III data from February 13 onwards. The estimated quarantine rate increased to 0.6185 from the previous 0.3917, with the total number of infected individuals now estimated at 49,510, indicating a hastened end to the epidemic. Similar analyses were conducted for Sichuan province (excluding Chengdu), the rest of the country (excluding Sichuan), and four tier-1 cities in China, all showing consistent trends. The model's predictions have proven to be highly accurate, underscoring the importance and efficacy of quarantine and control measures. Notably, Shanghai exhibited a reproductive number below 1 even with stage I data, suggesting a prompt and effective response to COVID-19. Further analysis revealed that Chengdu had the highest number of infected individuals in China, overwhelming local clinical resources and resulting in a low confirmation rate of 0.0643, compared to other regions. These findings support the necessity of stringent measures to contain the epidemic.

pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is represented by the rate of (1-g2)δ. We have established a set of ODE equations to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the control by artificial factors (Eq. 1). In this model, infected individuals can either go directly to being confirmed cases, or indirectly through quarantine. The direct route can be seen as a special case of the latter with zero delay time during quarantine. By simplifying the model as shown in Eq. 2, we can monitor and predict the disease trend using biologically meaningful parameters such as T=1/g1, which represents the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation, and w=1/(g2+(1-g2)), which denotes the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation. The reproductive number of the infection is R=α/g1. Parameter inference in the model involves using the number of cumulative confirmed infections, C(t), which is the only variable with daily observed data for model fitting and parameter estimation. The initial value of susceptible individuals, S(0), is assumed to be approximately equal to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections, C(0), is obtained from official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the outbreak of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China during Jan 25 and Jan 26. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this time period, confirmed infection numbers are considered to be less skewed and reflect the natural characteristics of COVID-19. Initially, numbers were small and fluctuating before Jan 25, influenced by strict quarantine measures in later stages. The parameter α is challenging to accurately estimate, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods or data sets. Fortunately, an exact value of α is not crucial in the SUQC model, as the overall infection ability, measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive in parameter optimization. This sensitivity helps balance any bias in α. Other parameters and initial values, such as g1, β, U(0), and Q(0), are determined by fitting daily confirmed infection data to the model. The expected daily confirmed infections, denoted as ^C=f(g1,β,U0,Q0), are calculated using the model and the fourth order Runge-Kutta method. The loss function, err(α,g1,U0,Q0), is optimized using the interior-point method in MATLAB to infer parameter values. Sensitivity analysis shows that the inferred values are not highly dependent on initial values. Different weighted loss functions are explored to better integrate information across the epidemic period.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and the economy. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Group of Research in Data Science and Computational Intelligence (ci ∂ic), the Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), and the Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais. Their research focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models, particularly the SEIR model. This article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Therefore, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the ongoing COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was reported on February 25th, 2020, leading to severe impact in the country. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil has recorded over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. The virus has not only caused a public health crisis but also affected various aspects of life including politics, education, economy, social issues, environment, climate, and global supply chains. Implementation of strict social distancing measures is crucial in combating the outbreak, as suggested by numerous studies. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying degrees of success, highlighting the challenge in predicting outcomes due to the complexity of societies.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: While initially focusing on epidemiological response variables, the simulation lacked accuracy in representing economic dynamics. The inclusion of social constructs like families and businesses, along with periodic routines such as working hours and bedtime, increased the feasibility of the simulation and boosted the performance of economic response variables compared to real-world values. These social constructs and routines are fixed but can be customized by users, with the parameter set offering flexibility to represent anything from a single community to an entire country. The following section delves into the experimental methodology, discussing the performance metrics and evaluation of seven scenarios reflecting various social distancing interventions. The ABS model was developed in Python version 3.6 and housed in the COVID_ABS package, with the source code available at https://bit.ly/covid_abs_experiments and https://bit.ly/COVID19_ABSsystem. Each scenario analyzes the impact of a specific social distancing policy on response variables outlined in Table 3, with 35 executions per scenario over 1,440 iterations each.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. The main goal of social interventions is to minimize the death curve D t . It is directly related to flattening the infection curve I t , in order to keep
post_context: t  cases below the critical limit of the healthcare system β 11 .Reducing the I t curve involves reducing the maximum infection peak I P, as outlined in Eq. author: chunwei
pre_context:
Uncertainties in data are considered by incorporating a probability distribution at each time point, with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance determined by the probability distribution, which may be influenced by the mean. The lack of data is a major concern for modelers, as it impacts the accuracy of predictions. The variability in model predictions can be attributed to how the available data on confirmed cases aligns with the model's projections. Confirmed cases are individuals with symptoms who have been tested and confirmed to have COVID-19. In transmission models, the infected compartment includes all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or testing. This means that confirmed cases are only a portion of the total infected population represented by model predictions. An iceberg is a fitting metaphor for this discrepancy, with the visible tip above the water symbolizing the confirmed cases, and the submerged part representing the hidden epidemic of infected individuals not captured by testing or surveillance.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? In the process of calibrating models, it is essential to accurately estimate key parameters such as the transmission rate (b) by comparing model output to confirmed cases data. This involves adjusting the model's prediction of the total number of infectious people (I(t)) by a case-infection ratio (r) in order to make accurate predictions of confirmed case data. The transmission rate (b) can then be determined for each value of r by fitting the model to the data, leading to the calculation of the basic reproduction number (R0), the scale of the epidemic, and the peak time. Due to the wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in the context of COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary widely, resulting in a wide range of model predictions. This variability is referred to as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, as different combinations of parameters can provide similar fits to the data but yield drastically different predictions. The handling of nonidentifiability during the model calibration process significantly impacts the reliability of model predictions. Traditional optimization algorithms like nonlinear least squares are not well-equipped to address nonidentifiability, as they may struggle to identify a global minimum due to the presence of infinitely many possible solutions.

pre_context:
Two days after symptoms appear, the WHO (2003) notes that the latent period for SARS is generally longer than the incubation period. Research on COVID-19 indicates that individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the exact duration of the latent period remains unknown. The SEIR model, while more biologically accurate than the SIR model, includes two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Diagrams illustrating the transfer process for both models can be found in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters in Tables 1 and 2. An important assumption for both models is that deaths in the susceptible, exposed, and infectious compartments are negligible over the course of the model predictions, which span four months. When calibrating the model using newly confirmed cases, the mortality factor in the recovered compartment does not impact the fit, as it is matched to the infectious term. The differential equations for each model are presented below:

Following the announcement at a news conference by the mayor of Chengdu on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population in Chengdu on January 20 to be around 6 million. Utilizing the same uniform distributions for initial parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models, we used the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to generate posterior distributions for all estimated parameters. The results provided best-fit values and 95% credible intervals. Comparing the SIR and SEIR models, the AICc values were calculated to be 174 and 186 respectively, with a difference of 12 indicating a significant loss of information when using the SEIR model. Therefore, we proceeded with further investigation using the SIR model. In our analysis, we also identified a linkage between the transmission rate and diagnosis rate, which will be explored further in subsequent research.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Using information gathered from a variety of sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, is essential for model calibration. This is particularly challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens that occur in real-time, such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 pandemic. One strategy to address this challenge is to improve inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce confidence intervals and enhance accuracy. Our fitting procedure, which utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Nanjing were generated by sampling the posterior distribution and are presented as prediction intervals. The parameter values and credible intervals used in the Bayesian inference were based on newly confirmed cases in Nanjing from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions period. These projections offer insights into the potential trajectory of the epidemic in Nanjing, assuming no further control measures were implemented after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Nanjing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 28, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimation, if the strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7th, the peak number of cases would have reached around 120,000, and the epidemic in Nanjing would likely have lasted until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with longer durations typically seen in more severe cases. In our model, we account for this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases (Table 1). Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2).

Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7, depending on factors such as population size and age structure. The β value of 0.016 used in our Covasim model was determined based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were chosen to align with other research on time use and known infection patterns. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can impact the transmission rate. Our model allows for variations in disease severity, time spent in different states, and individual infectiousness, which is determined by viral load. Studies have shown that viral load peaks around symptom onset and then decreases steadily. We model this with two stages of viral load: a high early stage and a lower later stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45, consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. Daily viral load adjusts the transmission probability for each individual. The proportion of transmissions by each contact layer is depicted in Fig 2 for a representative sample of individuals.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a computer model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals based on the acuity of their symptoms. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual with a probability of β, with a value of β = 0.016 representing a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7 for a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day. This value was calibrated to data from Washington and Oregon states and is currently the default in Covasim.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These ratios were selected to be consistent with existing research on time-use surveys and known contact types in infections. When combined with factors such as age-based susceptibility and the default number of contacts in each layer, a typical transmission scenario without interventions involves approximately 30% of transmission events occurring in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can modify the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness are accounted for by modeling variations in viral load. Studies have shown that viral load peaks around symptom onset and then decreases steadily. Our model incorporates two stages of viral load: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load values are determined by a negative binomial distribution, with adjustments made based on the daily viral load of an individual. Representations of viral loads for a sample of individuals are illustrated in Figure 2. Transmission by asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals is also considered.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is important for the user to calibrate the parameter described in Section 2.6.8 based on local epidemic data. The value of β, which depends on the contact type when realistic network structures such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts are included, has default transmission probabilities of 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were selected to align with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types. In the absence of interventions, a typical transmission scenario would see approximately 30% of transmission events occurring in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Individual infectiousness can also vary based on differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Olympia state and Washington. The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Figure 2 displays viral load data for a sample of individuals with default parameters. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location; estimated ratios for Seattle can be found in a previous study [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether the likelihood of transmission is lower in asymptomatic cases [55]. While we assume a default position that it is not lower, we acknowledge the possibility of adjusting this parameter based on the specific modeling scenario or context, considering that some research suggests lower rates of infectiousness in asymptomatic cases [61].
